Trolls can, if they are a very frequent occurance, at most delay your climb in the sense that they make the outcome of the game more random and thus less reliant on your actual skill.
But the law of big numbers combined with the fundamental idea of MMR make it pretty clear that this effect becomes negligible the further you are away from your "true" MMR and the more games you play.

In fact, the law of big numbers basically means trolls improve your chances of winning a game. If you never troll, the enemy team will on average have more trolls than your team.

> [{quoted}](name=leona4lyfe,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=aNcIbux3,comment-id=00020001000000000000000000000000000000010000000000010003,timestamp=2017-07-11T17:39:25.085+0000)

It doesn't matter as long as it's between 0 and 1.
Fluctuation doesn't matter for averages.

But fine here's your rigorous proof:
p = chance for a player being a troll (this can be presumed to be a static chance, since the playerbase is large enough)
P(X|A) = chance for X trolls in allied team
P(X|E) = chance for X trolls in enemy team
EA = Expectation value of trolls for allied team
EE = Expecttation value for trolls on the enemy team.

(1 - p = chance for a player **not** being a troll
chance for you to be a troll is presumed to be 0)

The expectation value for the amount of trolls then would be the sum of the values of each event (e.g. 3 for 3 trolls) multiplied with the chance of that event happening.

------------

EA = 0*P(0|A) + 1*P(1|A) + 2*P(2|A) + 3*P(3|A) + 4**P(4|A) + 5*P(5|A)

Since there is a 0% chance for five trolls on your team (you are not a troll) we can simplify this to:

EA = P(1|A) + 2*P(2|A) + 3*P(3|A) + 4*P(4|A)

------------------

EE = 0*P(0|E) + 1*P(1|E) + 2*P(2|E) + 3*P(3|E) + 4*P(4|E) + 5*P(5|E)

This time there is a chance for five trolls, but we can still simplify it to

EA = P(1|E) + 2*P(2|E) + 3*P(3|E) + 4**P(4|E) + 5*P(5|E)

----------------

Now, since we have a binomial distribution (each player can either be a troll or not, with the same chance; except for you with the chance being zero) we can conclude that the chances are:

P(X|A) = binom(4, X) * (1-p)^(4-X)  * p^X
P(X|E) = binom(5, X) * (1-p)^(5-X)  * p^X

or specifically:

P(1|A) = 4 * (1-p)^3 * p
P(1|E) = 5 * (1-p)^4  *  p
=> P(1|E) = 5/4 * (1-p) * P(1|A)

P(2|A) = 6 * (1-p)^2 * p^2
P(2|E) = 10  * (1-p)^3 * p^2
=> P(2|E) = 10/6 * (1-p) * P(2|A) = 5/3 * (1-p) * P(2|A)

P(3|A) = 4 * (1-p)^1 * p^3
P(3|E) = 10  * (1-p)^2 * p^3
=> P(3|E) = 10/4 * (1-p) * P(3|A) = 5/2 * (1-p) * P(3|A)

P(4|A) = 1 * (1-p)^0 * p^4
P(4|E) = 5 * (1-p)^1 * p^4
=> P(4|E) = 5/1 * (1-p) * P(4|A) = 5 * (1-p) * P(4|A)

P(5|A) = 0
P(5|E) = 1 * (1-p)^0 * p^5

------------------------

That means the expectation values are:

EA = 4 * (1-p)^3 * p + 12 * (1-p)^2 * p^2 + 12 * (1-p)^1 * p^3+ 4 * (1-p)^0 * p^4

and

EE = 5 * (1-p)^4  *  p + 20  * (1-p)^3 * p^2 + 30  * (1-p)^2 * p^3 + 20 * (1-p)^1 * p^4 + 5 * p^5

Now let's take a look at the difference:

EE - EA = 5 * (1-p)^4  *  p + 20  * (1-p)^3 * p^2 + 30  * (1-p)^2 * p^3 + 20 * (1-p)^1 * p^4 + 5 * p^5 - (4 * (1-p)^3 * p + 12 * (1-p)^2 * p^2 + 12 * (1-p)^1 * p^3+ 4 * (1-p)^0 * p^4)

-------------------------------------------

Now rather than showing you rigorous proof of why that is larger than zero, click the following link on Wolfram alpha in which you can check for yourself the values of this equation for values for p between 0 and 1 (aka 0% and 100%)

http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=5+*+(1-p)%5E4+*+p+%2B+20+*+(1-p)%5E3+*+p%5E2+%2B+30+*+(1-p)%5E2+*+p%5E3+%2B+20+*+(1-p)%5E1+*+p%5E4+%2B+5+*+p%5E5+-+(4+*+(1-p)%5E3+*+p+%2B+12+*+(1-p)%5E2+*+p%5E2+%2B+12+*+(1-p)%5E1+*+p%5E3%2B+4+*+(1-p)%5E0+*+p%5E4)+from+0+to+1

No matter the value for p (which is the value you accuse me of not knowing) EE-EA is positive, which means that EE is larger than EA.

Your team consists of four random players + you.
The enemy consists of four random players + one random player

Each of the groups of four random players obviously has the same amount of trolls on average and the same chance for X trolls for every X.
You have zero chance of being a troll if you are never a troll.
The last random player of the enemy team has a non-zero chance of being a troll.

So sometimes he will not be a troll (in which case you are tied)
and sometimes he will be a troll (in which case you have better odds)

If you are sometimes better off and sometimes equal, that means you are better off overall.
